race.name: Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: 5 days. 5 stages. The Grand Tour of American Gravel.

climate.description: Late June brings long days, warm temps, and Oregon's classic high desert conditions

terrain.primary: High desert and forest service gravel across Central Oregon
terrain.surface: Variable—smooth forest roads to chunky volcanic gravel

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Multi-day stage race format adds adventure value. Editorial +3 and overall +6.

biased_opinion.summary: Oregon Trail is for those who find single-day races limiting. The stage format creates different demands—recovery, consistency, pacing across days. It's closer to bikepacking than racing, with timing chips.
strengths: The format: Multi-day racing is a completely different experience.
The scenery: Central Oregon delivers world-class landscapes.
The community: Five days together creates real bonds.
weaknesses: Commitment: 5 days of racing requires serious vacation time.
Cost: Entry, lodging, travel adds up. This isn't a cheap race.
Logistics: Moving between towns requires planning or vehicle support.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you've exhausted one-day races and want something deeper, Oregon Trail is the next level. It's a proper cycling adventure disguised as a race.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Grand Tour of American gravel—five days of Oregon's best, compressed into one transformative experience.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you're ready for multi-day racing and want to experience gravel at its deepest. Not if you can't commit the time or prefer the intensity of one-day events.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want Oregon without 5-day commitment: Gorge Gravel Grinder. If you want multi-day elsewhere: Trans-Provence (Europe), Bike Nonstop (various).

logistics.airport: Portland (PDX) or Redmond (RDM) depending on stage locations.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Organized lodging packages available. Or book hotels in each stage town.
logistics.food: Event provides some meals. Small-town dining in stage communities.
logistics.packet_pickup: Day before Stage 1 at start location.
logistics.parking: Vehicle support recommended for gear transport between stages.

history.origin_story: Created as America's answer to European multi-day stage races. The format brings Grand Tour vibes to gravel, with towns hosting different stages and riders progressing through Oregon's spectacular landscapes.
notable_moments: Pioneered the multi-day gravel stage race format in America
Pioneered multi-day gravel stage racing format in the US
Known for spectacular course variety across stages
history.reputation: The gravel Grand Tour. Where one-day races feel limiting.

course_description.character: Five distinct stages showcasing Oregon's diversity—high desert, forests, mountains, and everything between.

suffering_zones.label: Opening Salvo
suffering_zones.desc: 60+ miles to set the tone. Fresh legs meet Oregon reality.

suffering_zones.label: The Queen Stage
suffering_zones.desc: The longest, hardest day. Where GC hopes live or die.

suffering_zones.label: Final Test
suffering_zones.desc: Tired bodies, one more day. Celebrate or suffer to the end.

course_description.signature_challenge: The cumulative nature. Any single stage is manageable. Five consecutive days of 60-80+ miles with major climbing is a different animal.

logistics.explanation: Five towns, daily gear transport, and full camp setup across Central Oregon creates complexity, but Morgan Cabot notes 'the Oregon Trail Gravel Grinder entry fee included camping and meals for the entire event.' Secured parking in Bend and packet pickup the day before shows organization, though managing logistics across multiple venues still creates potential failure points.

length.explanation: 375 miles over five days is proper stage race distance that accumulates serious fatigue. Morgan Cabot describes the strategic shift: 'After conservative and very social riding for the first 3 days, we decided to pick up the pace a little for the last two.' The multi-day format creates sustained expedition-length suffering, not just single-day endurance.

technicality.explanation: The Santiam Wagon Road delivers technical challenge - Morgan Cabot describes it as 'a sandpit/rock garden hybrid through 10+km of rolling hills' with 'a fair amount of tipping over and dismounting.' Jorge Padrones notes loose descents where 'you needed to concentrate as though the road was covered in ice.' However, much of the course runs on smoother gravel roads.

elevation.explanation: 35,000 feet over 375 miles means relentless climbing. Flo Costa set 'a 1 hour power PR' on a first climb alone, while Jorge Padrones faced a Queen Stage with 'two big climbs of more than 20 km' and '3000 elevation meters completed in the first 70 km.' The cumulative vertical is crushing across Central Oregon's high country.

climate.explanation: July in Central Oregon means hot, dry conditions with intense sun and potential afternoon winds. High desert climate is generally predictable - no mud years or weather disasters mentioned. The elevation changes from Bend to the Cascades create temperature swings, but nothing that derails the event regularly.

altitude.explanation: Starting in Bend at 3,600 feet and climbing into the Cascades creates noticeable elevation effects over five days. The cumulative 35,000 feet includes significant time above 4,000-5,000 feet across Central Oregon's high desert. While not crushing altitude, sea-level riders feel it compounding with multi-day fatigue by the later stages.

adventure.explanation: Five days of stage racing through Central Oregon's backcountry, sleeping in different towns each night, with full expedition support - this is proper adventure cycling. The route connects Bend, Gilchrist, Oakridge, and McKenzie Bridge across varied high desert and Cascade terrain. You're not just riding long, you're touring Oregon's gravel network with 90 other lunatics.

prestige.explanation: A 5-day stage race through Central Oregon with only 90 spots total? That's exclusive enough to matter. The race sells out and runs a waitlist, which tells you something about its reputation. Part of the Oregon Gravel Grinder Series Triple Challenge, but it's not pulling the big names or media coverage that would push it to legendary status.

race_quality.explanation: Five stages from Bend through Gilchrist, Oakridge, and McKenzie Bridge create proper stage race architecture with varied challenges. The course includes uphill/downhill time trials and technical wagon roads alongside high-speed gravel. Pete Stetina notes route changes 'giving more opportunities for people who are not super strong climbers for a chance of a stage win.'

experience.explanation: This is gravel camping done right - catered meals, nightly festivities, whiskey bar, massage add-ons, and mechanics all following you town to town. You get 'unmatched tales and friendship' because you're eating, drinking, and suffering with the same 90 people for five straight days. The VIP tent setup and daily gear transport mean you focus on riding, not logistics.

community.explanation: The intimate 90-rider field creates tight bonds through shared meals and camping, but limited size restricts broader community impact. Flo Costa appreciated 'extra time to sleep, eat, stretch' with 'great camp vibes' and 'plenty of down time to hang out with other athletes.' The multi-day format breeds connections among participants within the small field.

field_depth.explanation: Awards go to top 3 across pro, open, junior, masters, and masters plus categories, but no mention of prize money or notable pro participation. The 90-rider cap and $1,300+ entry fee suggests serious participants, not weekend warriors. Still, without big names or competitive depth mentioned anywhere, it's more adventure-focused than race-focused.

value.explanation: $1,300 minimum gets you 375 miles of racing, five days of meals, camping, support, and entertainment - that's reasonable cost-per-day for a supported stage race. The gear transport, mechanics, and daily camp setup justify the premium over single-day events. But you're still dropping serious cash for what's essentially a supported tour with timing chips.

expenses.explanation: Entry starts at $1,300 and hits $1,800 for late registration, plus you need to get to Bend and potentially add massage/VIP tent upgrades. RV camping runs $30-35/night extra, and the whiskey bar won't be free. Central Oregon in July means hotel rates are peak season if you skip the camping experience.
